entry.title: Heartfulness
entry.content:
In Chinese, the word for mind is the same word for heart. So, "mindfulness" in Chinese could either mean "having the mind in the present" or it could mean "having the heart in the present".

Ironically, mindfulness involves less thinking and more being.

Therefore, I think "heartfulness" is the word we're looking for when we describe being fully present in the moment.

entry.title: Do To Become Better
entry.content:
Writers get better by writing more. Weightlifters get stronger by lifting more. Painters get better by painting more.

What do you want to get better at?

Do more of that.

entry.title: Experiment
entry.content:
Inputs make outputs. Make experiments where you compare an outcome to the actions you made.

If you are happy with the outcome, keep doing what you're doing, otherwise start doing something else.

entry.title: Negative Space
entry.content:
Beauty often stems from the contrast of negativity.

  • What would music be without moments of silence?
  • What would dancing be without moments of stillness?
  • What would graphical art be without negative space?
  • What would victory be without the possibility of defeat?

entry.title: Have the Courage to be Imperfect
entry.content:
According to Alfred Adler, everyone has an innate desire to achieve mastery and superiority. Ironically, the only way to achieve mastery is admit inferiority and learn from mistakes.

It is up to us to determine what mistakes mean to us. They can either be a failure or a stepping stone to success. Hence one of Adler's best pieces of advice:

Have the courage to be imperfect.

entry.title: Consequences of Meaning
entry.content:
Humans are meaning-making machines. We are compelled to place meaning on everything that surrounds us.

Things get hard when we experience more complex events where we struggle to provide a meaningful explanation.

It is a struggle because the meaning that we define dictates our plan to respond. Going against the plan makes us feel terrible until we create new meaning that we are willing to act upon.
